author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: More Aid to Ukraine
description: Plus China’s advantage in the Pacific and Shanghai’s loosening restrictions.
content: A day after the European Union agreed to punish Russia with an oil embargo, European leaders announced a 9 billion euro aid package for Ukraine and moved to tackle the backlog of Ukrainian crops that is threatening a global food crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Benjamin Mullin
title: Forbes, Chronicler of Wealthy and Powerful, Will Scrap Plan to Go Public via SPAC
description: The century-old business magazine had aimed to go public through a blank-check company based in Hong Kong but changed course after the market flipped.
content: Forbes, the wealth-obsessed business publication, has decided to call off a deal to go public through a special-purpose acquisition company, also known as a SPAC, amid cooling investor appetite for the once-popular financial instrument, two people with knowledge of the plans said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: May 31, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Tuesday, May 31, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley and Jose A. Alvarado Jr
title: When the Only Way to Get to Work Is This Slow Bus
description: The Q23 is one of the slowest buses in Queens, where many residents live beyond the subway’s reach and more people ride buses than anywhere else in New York City.
content: Just beyond the reach of New York City’s frenetic, round-the-clock subway, people in a slice of western Queens wait — and wait — to board one of the borough’s slowest buses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Student Contest Winner: The Story of a Holocaust Survivor
description: Charles Heller learned he was part Jewish only when his relatives began to disappear.
content: This piece is one of 10 winners of our 2022 Profile Contest. You can find more here. Talia Dauer, the author, is 17 and goes to Greenhill School in Addison, Texas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: E.U. Bans Most Russian Oil
description: The embargo will bruise a cornerstone of Russia’s economy.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Thousands of Sievierodonetsk Civilians Trapped as Russian Forces Advance
description: The eastern Ukrainian city’s younger residents have largely evacuated, leaving older citizens to bear the brunt of Moscow’s assault.
content: Fighting raged in Sievierodonetsk on Tuesday as Russian troops advanced toward the center of a city that has become a central focus for President Vladimir V. Putin’s forces since they failed to seize Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, early in the war and pivoted to the east of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Too Much Talent for a Tiny League
description: Making it to the pros is always hard. But with only 12 teams with 12 players each, the W.N.B.A. makes it seemingly impossible for too many women’s college basketball stars.
content: Raina Perez is used to staring down obstacles. It’s not just her sport, women’s basketball, which seems forever in the shadow of the men’s game. It’s not just her height, 5 feet 4 inches — diminutive, even for a point guard. It’s not just that she is Mexican American, and that there are few Mexican American stars in the world of hoops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: It’s Doom Times in Tech
description: Will this meltdown permanently damage the tech world, or is this one more temporary blip?
content: The tech industry is experiencing an earthquake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitra Taj
title: ‘Allinllachu.’ Google Translate Adds Quechua to Its Platform.
description: The addition of one of the most widely spoken Indigenous languages in the Americas could help public servants and health workers connect with their communities. (And by the way, “allinllachu” means hello.)
content: LIMA — When Irma Alvarez Ccoscco heard that the language she has spoken her entire life, Quechua, had been added to Google Translate, she hurried to her computer to try it out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Golembiewski
title: The World’s Largest Plant Is a Self-Cloning Sea Grass in Australia
description: The species is called Poseidon’s ribbon weed, and researchers say it has spread to cover an area the size of Cincinnati over the past 4,500 years.
content: In Shark Bay, off the westernmost tip of Australia, meadows of sea grass carpet the ocean floor, undulating in the current and being nibbled on by dugongs, cousins of Florida manatees. A new study revealed something unexpected about those sea grasses: Many of them are the same individual plant that has been cloning itself for about 4,500 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: Walter Abish, Daring Writer Who Pondered Germany, Dies at 90
description: In provocative, sometimes linguistically playful experimental fiction, a Vienna-born American traced the complex interplay of modern Germany and its Nazi past.
content: Walter Abish, a widely admired if not widely read American author of experimental fiction whose early life drew a parabola of hasty escapes from hostile forces in Nazi-era Austria and revolutionary China, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Drew Gilpin Faust
title: White and Black: A Historian Traces African-American Influences in the United States
description: David Hackett Fischer’s “African Founders” examines the interplay of Black and white culture through the centuries.
content: AFRICAN FOUNDERSHow Enslaved People Expanded American IdealsBy David Hackett Fischer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
title: Peter Navarro, Former Trump Aide, Gets Grand Jury Subpoena in Jan. 6 Inquiry
description: The subpoena, the latest indication of an expanding inquiry by federal prosecutors, seeks Mr. Navarro’s testimony and any records he has related to the attack on the Capitol last year.
content: Peter Navarro, who as a White House adviser to President Donald J. Trump worked to keep Mr. Trump in office after his defeat in the 2020 election, disclosed on Monday that he has been summoned to testify on Thursday to a federal grand jury and to provide prosecutors with any records he has related to the attack on the Capitol last year, including “any communications” with Mr. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatriz Williams
title: How to Prevent Unwanted Pregnancies? Lock Up ‘Unfit’ Women.
description: Ann Leary’s novel, “The Foundling,” may sound like dystopian satire — but it’s not.
content: In the introductory note to “The Foundling,” Ann Leary suggests a conundrum. How could an “early feminist” like Margaret Sanger — a pioneer of reproductive freedom, a tireless activist for progressive reform — proclaim in 1922 that “every feebleminded girl or woman of the hereditary type, especially of the moron class, should be segregated during the reproductive period” and expect modern-thinking people to agree with her?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Student Contest Winner: A Different Vision of Iowa Farming
description: Lynn Sutton, a community activist turned urban farmer, addresses social inequality one garden at a time.
content: This piece is one of 10 winners of our 2022 Profile Contest. You can find more here. Lilah Takes, the author, is 17 and goes to Wahlert Catholic High School in Dubuque, Iowa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: To House Refugees, Lviv Wants to Make Beautiful Buildings That Last
description: The Ukrainian city’s distinctive architecture has made it a world heritage site. Its architects are trying to balance aesthetics with sustainability as it prepares for a long war.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — To stand in the cobblestone square that is this city’s historic marketplace is to be surrounded by the influences captured in brick, stone and plaster of cultures intersecting and of empires rising and falling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Prosecutors Open New Inquiry Into Mysterious Deaths of Prominent Couple
description: New Jersey’s acting attorney general is investigating the 2014 deaths of Joyce and John Sheridan, a former state transportation commissioner.
content: The New Jersey attorney general’s office has opened an investigation into the unsolved deaths of a prominent political couple whose bodies were found in their home near Princeton, N.J., nearly eight years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas Greenwood
title: Becoming Johnny Rotten, When John Lydon Would Rather You Didn’t
description: Anson Boon went through a grueling process to play the punk star in “Pistol,” even though the original wanted nothing to do with the project.
content: LONDON — Anson Boon gave playing Johnny Rotten everything he had, including a front tooth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: Megalodons vs. Great White Sharks? We Know Which Predator Won.
description: The largest shark that ever lived may have vanished in part because the comparatively smaller great white had a taste for the same prey.
content: Twenty million years ago, a predator with a mouth like a subway door and teeth the size of your palm roamed the seas. The megalodon, the largest shark ever to live on Earth, could grow more than 50 feet long, and it was the scourge of the ocean for millions of years. Then it disappeared. The megalodon was no more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Even as Russia Bears Down in the East, Some Ukrainians Stay Behind
description: The Russian offensive grinds on, but not everyone is leaving the eastern Donbas region.
content: BAKHMUT, Ukraine — The volunteers listened patiently to the pensioner and stuffed a frozen chicken into her shopping bag.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Erika Bachiochi
description: A conversation with the legal scholar
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Erika Bachiochi. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: How Putin Has Played His Energy Cards
description: The energy realists Jason Bordoff and Meghan O’Sullivan explain why the Ukraine war means a very bumpy ride in the transition off of fossil fuels.
content: Almost as soon as the war in Ukraine began, in February, I found myself returning to an essay published online in Foreign Affairs in November. In “Green Upheaval,” Jason Bordoff and Meghan O’Sullivan predict that global decarbonization, while necessary, will not be the glide path to a peaceful green future that many climate activists imagine. They say that decarbonization will instead be a great disruption to geopolitics, in which many conventional assumptions about who would “win” and who would “lose” in the green transition would be shown to be naïve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Student Contest Winner: Halal Noodles in Shanghai
description: Haronnae Wang’s Muslim customers tell him, “It’s hard to find halal food in Shanghai, and this tastes like home.”
content: This piece is one of 10 winners of our 2022 Profile Contest. You can find more here. Stephanie Chen, the author, is 16 and goes to Shanghai American School, Pudong Campus, in Shanghai.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Michael Sussmann Is Acquitted in Case Brought by Trump-Era Prosecutor
description: The Democratic-linked lawyer was accused of lying to the F.B.I. about his clients when he passed on a tip about possible connections between Donald J. Trump and Russia.
content: WASHINGTON — Michael Sussmann, a prominent cybersecurity lawyer with ties to Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign, was acquitted on Tuesday of lying to the F.B.I. in 2016 when he shared a tip about possible connections between Donald J. Trump and Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Subway Victim Sues Gun Maker Over Attack That ‘Changed My Life Forever’
description: Ilene Steur, who was shot in the Sunset Park attack in April, argued that Glock markets its firearms by emphasizing qualities that make them attractive to criminals.
content: Ilene Steur was about halfway through her morning commute to her real-estate job when smoke suddenly began to fill her subway car, a man seats away began firing shots, and she was struck by a bullet in her buttocks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: In Astoria’s Little Egypt, Making a Case for Tagines From Morocco
description: The seductively nuanced stews are the stars of a new Queens restaurant, Dar Yemma.
content: My first encounter with a real Moroccan tagine was 30 years ago in the home of a taxi driver who had invited me to dinner with his family in Fes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Harry Styles Is No. 1 With a Record-Breaking Total for Vinyl Sales
description: “Harry’s House,” the British pop star’s third solo album, moved more copies on vinyl since at least 1991, when SoundScan began keeping reliable sales data.
content: Is 500,000 the new million?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph R. Biden Jr
title: President Biden: What America Will and Will Not Do in Ukraine
description: The U.S. will help Ukraine be in the strongest possible position at the negotiating table. We do not want to prolong the war just to inflict pain on Russia.
content: The invasion Vladimir Putin thought would last days is now in its fourth month. The Ukrainian people surprised Russia and inspired the world with their sacrifice, grit and battlefield success. The free world and many other nations, led by the United States, rallied to Ukraine’s side with unprecedented military, humanitarian and financial support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danya Issawi
title: Drew Afualo, TikTok Star, Goes On a New York Breakfast Crawl
description: A bagel, an iced latte, a berry tart and a conversation with the feminist firebrand about the ups and downs of online fame.
content: On a recent morning, the social media star Drew Afualo stepped into Tompkins Square Bagels, a deli in the East Village of Manhattan. After glancing at the descriptions of the elaborate breakfast sandwiches on the chalkboard menu, she ordered something simple: an everything bagel, toasted, with butter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Collision Course for 2 Stalwart Manhattan Democrats
description: A court-ordered redistricting plan puts Representatives Carolyn Maloney and Jerrold Nadler in a primary against each other.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at why two Democrats who were longtime allies have become opponents. We’ll also check in on London’s new train line and the top official at Transport for London, who used to be in charge of the subways in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Fuhrer
title: ‘Baseball Players Don’t Dance’? The Savannah Bananas Beg to Differ.
description: TikTok choreography, dancing umpires, a ballet-trained first-base coach: This collegiate summer league team has amassed a following by leaning into entertainment.
content: How does a dance writer from the Northeast end up fixated on a collegiate summer league baseball team from Savannah, Ga.?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Eurozone inflation hits its highest level since the creation of the euro in 1999.
description: The economic toll of Russia’s war on Ukraine keeps widening, with price rises in Germany hitting a record and inflation in Estonia topping 20 percent.
content: Inflation in the euro area in May hit its highest annual level since the creation of the euro currency in 1999, Europe’s statistics agency reported on Tuesday, as a record run-up in energy and food prices stoked by Russia’s war in Ukraine continued to ricochet through the continent’s economy, raising the specter of a lapse into recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and David E. Sanger
title: Seizing Russian Assets to Help Ukraine Sets Off White House Debate
description: Some European officials want to use more than $300 billion in Russian central bank assets to rebuild Ukraine. But Biden administration officials warn that diverting those funds could be illegal.
content: WASHINGTON — The devastation in Ukraine brought on by Russia’s war has leaders around the world calling for seizing more than $300 billion of Russian central bank assets and handing the funds to Ukraine to help rebuild the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawna Richer
title: Rangers Hand Hurricanes First Home Loss of the Playoffs to Advance
description: Chris Kreider scored twice and Igor Shesterkin was nearly perfect in the 6-2 win. New York will play the Tampa Bay Lightning in the Eastern Conference finals.
content: The question entering Monday night wasn’t whether the Rangers could win an elimination game or a high-stakes Game 7; it was whether they could beat the Carolina Hurricanes away from Madison Square Garden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: A European embargo on Russian oil.
content: The E.U. agreed yesterday to ban most imports of Russian oil, the harshest economic penalty yet imposed for Russia’s invasion of Ukraine and potentially Europe’s biggest sacrifice. The bloc had already cut off Russian banks, frozen Russian assets and sent advanced weaponry to Ukraine. Follow the latest updates from the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Omaha Residents Are Urged to Evacuate After Chemical Fire
description: The three-alarm fire sent clouds of smoke billowing over the city. There were no immediate reports of injuries.
content: The authorities in Omaha urged some residents to evacuate on Monday after a three-alarm fire at a chemical plant sent clouds of black smoke billowing over the city, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Tea to Celebrate a Big Anniversary
description: Pearls are the traditional gift for a 30th anniversary, so the Republic of Tea is now offering Jasmine Pearls, a new tea, to commemorate its 1992 founding.
content: The Republic of Tea was founded in 1992 and then acquired two years later by Ron Rubin, an entrepreneur who worked in the beer, wine and liquor business before starting a bottled beverage company. It’s called the Republic of Tea because some of the original owners also created the Banana Republic clothing company. Mr. Rubin and members of his family run the company; his son, Todd Rubin is now the chief executive. Their focus is on issues like sustainability, green manufacturing, fair labor practices and the like. To commemorate its 30th anniversary, the company has introduced a new jasmine tea, Jasmine Pearls. It’s a green tea made by tightly hand-rolling buds and leaves that have been dried with jasmine buds into fragrant little orbs that gently unfurl in response to hot water and produce an amber-colored beverage of great depth and fragrance to serve hot or cold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: California Has America’s Toughest Gun Laws, and They Work
description: As in the “Swiss cheese model” of Covid prevention, a lot of small measures add up.
content: The grotesque toll of gun violence is again being debated in Congress. As Luis Ferré-Sadurní and I reported over the long weekend, states are not holding their breath.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Lester Piggott, Superstar British Jockey, Dies at 86
description: He won his first race at age 12 and his last in his 50s, and he rode to a record 30 victories in the five most important British thoroughbred races.
content: Lester Piggott, one of Britain’s greatest jockeys, who won nearly 4,500 races on his native soil but whose yearlong imprisonment for tax fraud in the 1980s detoured the latter part of his career, died on Sunday near Geneva. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: A Farewell and the Promise of a New Future at City Ballet
description: The company’s spring season, a double whammy of Covid and injury, ended with the retirement of the principal Amar Ramasar.
content: What stood out? What stood still? Who was still standing?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies and Lanna Apisukh
title: The Crypto Bros Are Snapping Up Manhattan Real Estate
description: Cryptocurrency firms have been setting up or expanding office space in New York, but the recent market turbulence could hamper their longevity.
content: The cryptocurrency market has been in a meltdown. Digital currencies, along with other blockchain-based properties, have plunged in value, lending credence to skeptics who have regarded the crypto phenomenon as a fad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas F. Madden
title: Looking for Europe’s Future in an Overlooked Corner of the Continent
description: Robert D. Kaplan’s “Adriatic” takes readers on a political, intellectual and personal tour from Italy to Albania.
content: ADRIATICA Concert of Civilizations at the End of the Modern AgeBy Robert D. Kaplan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Sex, Abortion and Feminism, as Seen From the Right
description: The socially conservative legal scholar Erika Bachiochi argues that abortion rights have stalled women’s progress toward equality.
content: For decades, the conservative position on abortion has been simple: Appoint justices who will overturn Roe V. Wade. That aspiration is now likely to become reality. The question of abortion rights will re-enter the realm of electoral politics in a way it hasn’t for 50 years. And that means Republicans will need to develop a new politics of abortion — a politics that may appeal not only to their anti-abortion base but to some of the many Americans who believe Roe should stand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan O'Callaghan
title: Pale Blue, Deep Blue: How Uranus and Neptune Get Their Colors
description: While the giant, icy worlds are similar in many ways, a thinner, more active haze makes Neptune more blue than Uranus.
content: Roses are red. Neptune’s deep blue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Our readers sent updates on stories that have resonated with many of you.
description: More than 20,000 readers have written in to share their pandemic experiences.
content: The New York Times’s coronavirus newsletter debuted in March 2020, and we asked readers to send their stories about how they were coping with the virus. Since then, more than 20,000 readers have written in to share their pandemic experiences.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Senate Chasing an Ever-Elusive Gun Law Deal
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, May 31, 2022.
content: “When people give up on us dealing with the most important and most existential issues, it means they’re giving up on democracy itself.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias
title: The Arrow in America’s Heart
description: Relentless mass shootings, a million dead from Covid — How much do we value a single life?
content: Two days after the massacre of children in Uvalde, Texas, and 12 days after the racist mass killing in Buffalo, Chenxing Han, a chaplain and teacher, told a Buddhist parable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Harlan
title: Love and Trauma in the Wilds of California
description: The author Nina LaCour is known for her young adult novels. She is making her adult debut with a tale of two women finding themselves, and each other.
content: When Sara, one of the protagonists in “Yerba Buena,” was a girl, she and her family used to play a game. They started with a blank piece of paper. Each person in turn would begin to sketch, slowly building the scene. As Sara and her brother watched, “their father moved his pencil, faint lines that turned — as if by magic — into places and things they recognized.” Suddenly, there it was: an entire world, familiar yet strange, and within it, a story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Student Contest Winner: Told He Had Six Months to Live, He Opened an Art Exhibit
description: After Kim Gyoo-sik was named an artist of the year in a national contest, he learned he had late-stage cancer. But even now, he’s thinking of ideas for a new project.
content: This piece is one of 10 winners of our 2022 Profile Contest. You can find more here. Nathan Ko, the author, is 17 and goes to the The Loomis Chaffee School in Windsor, Conn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Jeanna Smialek
title: Biden and Fed chair Powell meet as inflation dogs the global economy.
description: Big risks threaten economic growth around the world as central banks try to bring prices under control.
content: President Biden met with Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, at the White House on Tuesday, as part of an effort to both sell Americans on a brightening view of the economy and reassure consumers that leaders in Washington are hard at work to slow rapidly rising prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Coast Guard Admiral to Become First Female Service Chief, Shattering Another Glass Ceiling
description: In 1985, the service had no gender-based prohibitions on where women could go. That cleared the way for Admiral Linda L. Fagan to rise to the top.
content: Adm. Linda L. Fagan will shatter one of the last glass ceilings in the military on Wednesday when she takes the oath as commandant of the Coast Guard and becomes the first female officer to lead a branch of the American armed forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Jenny Gross
title: Tightening the Squeeze on Russia
description: What an embargo means for oil prices, plus a one-issue candidate whose issue is Elon Musk.
content: Late last night, the European Union agreed to ban Russian oil imports arriving by sea by the end of the year. The agreement, which was reached after weeks of wrangling among E.U. member states, could cut into Moscow’s ability to finance its invasion of Ukraine. The embargo applies to most oil imports from Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller and Eleanor Lutz
title: During the Omicron Wave, Death Rates Soared for Older People
description: Last year, people 65 and older died from Covid at lower rates than in previous waves. But with Omicron and waning immunity, death rates rose again.
content: Despite strong levels of vaccination among older people, Covid killed them at vastly higher rates during this winter’s Omicron wave than it did last year, preying on long delays since their last shots and the variant’s ability to skirt immune defenses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai and Catherine Porter
title: Canada Decriminalizes Opioids and Other Drugs in British Columbia
description: With opioid deaths skyrocketing in the western province, Canada has temporarily decriminalized the substance and three others for personal use.
content: Facing soaring levels of opioid deaths since the pandemic began in 2020, the Canadian government announced Tuesday that it would temporarily decriminalize the possession of small amounts of illegal drugs, including cocaine and methamphetamines, in the western province of British Columbia that has been ground zero for the country’s overdoses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary Phillips
title: Surrounded by Injuries, a Mets Fill-In Hopes to Stick Around
description: With the aces Max Scherzer and Jacob deGrom out, David Peterson has been surprisingly dependable. The Mets have yet to lose a game he started.
content: David Peterson knows what it is like to be the injured pitcher stuck on the sideline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Student Contest Winner: Haenyeo, Real-Life Aquawomen
description: Lee Ji-hye is part of a society of female divers who harvest sea creatures. Pollution and climate change are threatening her livelihood.
content: This piece is one of 10 winners of our 2022 Profile Contest. You can find more here. Haedam Lee, 14, and Yeonji Joo, 13, the authors, go to Branksome Hall Asia in Seogwipo City, South Korea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Marvin Josephson, Who Scored Big Deals for Stars, Dies at 95
description: He started small as a talent agent in 1955, with an unknown kiddie TV performer who would soon become Captain Kangaroo.
content: Marvin Josephson’s beginnings as a talent agent in the mid-1950s were humble, to say the least. His main client — practically his only client then, in fact — was Bob Keeshan, the children’s television performer who, with Mr. Josephson’s help, would become known far and wide as Captain Kangaroo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rob Szypko, Stella Tan, M.J. Davis Lin, Lisa Chow, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano and Corey Schreppel
title: Why the Police Took 78 Minutes to Stop the Uvalde Gunman
description: In the days since the shooting, questions have abounded about the response from law enforcement officers.
content: After the shooting at Robb Elementary School in Uvalde, Texas, the explanation for how the police acted kept shifting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Kevin Spacey to Voluntarily Travel to Britain to Face Sexual Assault Charges
description: The actor said in a statement to “Good Morning America” that he will seek to prove his innocence against the charges.
content: The actor Kevin Spacey said on Tuesday that he will voluntarily travel to Britain to face criminal sexual assault charges, allowing the authorities there to formally charge him without having to pursue extradition proceedings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Wall Street’s Losing Streak Ends, but Uncertainty That Drove It Lingers
description: As stocks have tumbled this year, predictions that the selling is over have been wrong time and again.
content: The stock market’s staggering run of losses came to an end last week, with the S&P 500 snapping a seven-week losing streak and pulling away from the brink of a bear market with a 6.6 percent bounce through Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik and Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Alexander Zverev Beats Carlos Alcaraz at the French Open
description: Zverev, the No. 3 seed, will face either No. 5 Rafael Nadal or No. 1 Novak Djokovic in the semifinal round.
content: PARIS — Alexander Zverev, the No. 3 seed, returned to the semifinals of the French Open with a 6-4, 6-4, 4-6, 7-6 (7) victory over Carlos Alcaraz on Tuesday, ending the Spanish 19-year-old’s stirring run at Roland Garros.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: Finger Foods, an Investigation
description: At these restaurants, you’ll be using your hands.
content: Sorry in advance for the frequent use of the phrase “finger foods” in this newsletter. As a society, we have got to come up with something more appealing. Hand cuisine? Digit diet? Those two options are even worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Student Contest Winner: Energy Empowers Her
description: Heather Shilton is collaborating with Inuit communities to bring renewable energy to Canada’s northernmost territory.
content: This piece is one of 10 winners of our 2022 Profile Contest. You can find more here. Katie Yu, the author, is 16 and goes to Inuksuk High School in Nunavut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Burns
title: To Enjoy Life More, Embrace Anticipation
description: Looking forward to something can be almost as good as experiencing it.
content: Alle Pierce knows how to plan a vacation. A few months out, she “goes on a crazy Google spree,” constructing a spreadsheet of all the things she wants to do and see. She scrutinizes the menus of restaurants she’s planning to visit. She uses a picture of the destination as her phone’s lock screen image and downloads a countdown app.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laleh Khadivi
title: A Debut Novel About Two Couples, Divided by Countries and Creeds
description: “Planes,” by Peter C. Baker, explores the internal lives of four characters in a story of activism, duty and culpability.
content: Amira. Ayoub. Melanie. Bradley. The names alone evoke 21st-century literary tension. Muslims, non-Muslims, men, women. There must be a story here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Hepatitis A Outbreak in U.S. and Canada Linked to Strawberries
description: The F.D.A. said the likely source of the outbreak was fresh organic strawberries that were sold under the FreshKampo and H-E-B brands in March and April.
content: Public health officials said they were investigating an outbreak of hepatitis A in the United States and Canada that is potentially linked to organic strawberries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Student Contest Winner: From Field Labor to an Engineering Major
description: Jesus Trujillo is good at sorting broccoli, but he dreams of developing artificial intelligence harvesters that can do it better.
content: This piece is one of 10 winners of our 2022 Profile Contest. You can find more here. Anna Yang, the author, is 17 and goes to Notre Dame High School in San Jose, Calif.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Keep Bumping Into
description: Take a break with this puzzle from Sam Buchbinder and Brad Wilber.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Today’s puzzle comes to us from two seasoned constructors whom we keep bumping into: Sam Buchbinder, who is making his 10th appearance in the New York Times Crossword, and Brad Wilber, who is making his 60th. This is also Mr. Wilber’s 33rd collaboration, with his 13th collaborator — that’s some significant co-constructing!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: An Asbury Park Victorian Gets a ‘Really Fun’ Face-Lift
description: The playful renovation preserved many of the home’s original details, but emphasized carefree weekend living.
content: Matt Berman and Jim Mumma discovered Asbury Park, N.J., well before its revitalization was in full swing, when whispers about the neglected oceanfront city were just starting to reach Manhattanites in search of a weekend escape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Communities and Conversations: Meet the People Featured in Our Winning Student Profiles
description: Teenagers from India to Iowa interviewed and photographed fascinating local people. Here are 10 of their subjects.
content: Our first-ever Profile Contest asked a lot of its teenage participants. Not only did they have to find someone interesting to interview, then develop questions designed to draw that person out, but they had to edit the resulting conversation into a cogent and compelling Q. and A. of no more than 700 words. In addition, they were asked to take at least one “environmental portrait” of their subject and supply a caption for it, as well as write a headline for their piece.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: 2 Russian Soldiers Sentenced in Ukrainian War-Crimes Trial
description: The soldiers, an artillery driver and a gunner, had been found guilty of shelling the town of Derhachi in northeastern Ukraine.
content: A court in central Ukraine sentenced two Russian soldiers on Tuesday to 11 and a half years in prison for shelling a town in the country’s northeast during the war. It was the second guilty verdict handed down by Ukrainian courts for war crimes since Russia’s full-scale invasion began in February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Caldwell
title: The War in Ukraine May Be Impossible to Stop. And the U.S. Deserves Much of the Blame.
description: A tragic, local and ambiguous conflict has been turned into a potential world conflagration.
content: In the Paris daily Le Figaro this month, Henri Guaino, a top adviser to Nicolas Sarkozy when he was president of France, warned that Europe’s countries, under the shortsighted leadership of the United States, were “sleepwalking” into war with Russia. Mr. Guaino was borrowing a metaphor that the historian Christopher Clark used to describe the origins of World War I.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: In ‘Romeo & Bernadette,’ It’s Off to Brooklyn for This Tale of Joy
description: In this sweet, spoofy romp of a musical comedy, Romeo awakens from a 400-year slumber and follows a Juliet look-alike to Brooklyn.
content: Cutting a lovelorn swath through 1960 Brooklyn in search of his Juliet, Romeo Montague is as charming as ever, with his courtly manner and his embroidered speech so different from the local patois.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: Why China Is Miles Ahead in a Pacific Race for Influence
description: To many observers, the South Pacific today reveals what American decline looks like. Even as Washington tries to step up its game, it is still far behind, mistaking speeches for impact and interest for influence.
content: SUVA, Fiji — Take a walk through the city where China’s foreign minister met on Monday with the leaders of nearly a dozen Pacific Island nations, and China’s imprint is unmistakable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Blocks Texas Law Regulating Social Media Platforms
description: The law, prompted by conservative complaints about censorship, prohibits big technology companies like Facebook and Twitter from removing posts based on the views they express.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday blocked a Texas law that would ban large social media companies from removing posts based on the views they express.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Why Masks Work, but Mandates Haven’t
description: Why haven’t Covid mask mandates made much difference?
content: Covid cases and hospitalizations are rising again in the U.S., and deaths are starting to rise, too. In response, many people are understandably asking what the country can do to minimize the virus’s toll in the weeks ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: From Gun Laws to Abortion, 5 Issues for N.Y. Legislators as Session Ends
description: A move to raise the minimum age to buy AR-15-style weapons is among several hot-button issues still to be resolved in Albany before the session ends.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — Money and lobbying hold enormous sway in the State Capitol, but there are few pressures like an old-fashioned deadline to get major legislation over the finish line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: French Diplomats to Strike Over Loss of Separate Status
description: President Emmanuel Macron wants more flexibility to move senior officials between roles, but diplomats see a demotion and potential cronyism.
content: PARIS — When France, land of Talleyrand and the general strike, decides to abolish the heart of its diplomatic corps at a time of war in Europe, it is perhaps only natural that its diplomats should respond with fierce indignation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: ‘Tracy Flick Can’t Win’ Catches Up With a Hard-Luck High Achiever
description: Tom Perrotta’s sequel to “Election” finds Flick, the character immortalized in film by Reese Witherspoon, reconsidering her past.
content: Tom Perrotta’s characters commit routine moral crimes: They betray spouses, treat friends shabbily, send inappropriate text messages, disrespect their parents, scheme to unseat rivals. These people aren’t serial killers or Marvel villains; their sins are prosaic. Twenty years ago, Us Weekly magazine launched a feature called “Stars — They’re Just Like Us!” which depicted celebrities buying dog kibble or waiting for luggage at the airport. You can’t read a novel like “The Leftovers” or “Mrs. Fletcher” without a similar thought flashing across your mind: “Tom Perrotta Characters — They’re Just Like Us!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: These Reboots of Cartoon Classics Are Exceptional, Delightful Art
description: Looney Tunes and Disney delivered wit and joy in their updates on old favorites.
content: During these times so utterly glum, I’m in a mood to share a couple of discoveries that have provided a bit of joy, which I hope will bring some joy to you and, if you’re a parent, your kids as well. Two pandemic delights, to be specific, which I’ve held on to as life gropes toward some form of normalcy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
title: They Insisted the 2020 Election Was Tainted. Their 2022 Primary Wins? Not So Much.
description: Republicans are accepting their primary victories with little concern about the voter fraud they once falsely claimed caused Donald J. Trump’s loss.
content: This spring, when Representative Mo Brooks of Alabama was fighting to win over conservatives in his campaign for Senate, he ran a television ad that boasted, “On Jan. 6, I proudly stood with President Trump in the fight against voter fraud.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Shaw and John Bash
title: We Clerked for Justices Scalia and Stevens. America Is Getting Heller Wrong.
description: The decision has been misused in important policy debates about our nation’s gun laws.
content: In the summer of 2008, the Supreme Court decided District of Columbia v. Heller, in which the court held for the first time that the Second Amendment protected an individual right to gun ownership. We were law clerks to Justice Antonin Scalia, who wrote the majority opinion, and Justice John Paul Stevens, who wrote the lead dissent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: F.A.A. limits self-regulation privileges for Boeing.
description: The agency approved only a three-year renewal, it said, because it wants to ensure that Boeing is carrying out certain changes to the program.
content: The Federal Aviation Administration said on Tuesday that it had issued Boeing a shorter extension than the company had sought to conduct some of its own regulatory checks, as the agency works to reform the practice of outsourcing regulatory authority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: E.U. reaches agreement on a Russian oil import ban.
description: BRUSSELS — European Union leaders have reached a landmark political agreement to ban the vast majority of Russian oil imports by the end of the year, a measure that was considered impossible in the early stages of the Russian invasion of Ukraine because of the bloc’s high dependency on the fuel.
content: BRUSSELS — European Union leaders have reached a landmark political agreement to ban the vast majority of Russian oil imports by the end of the year, a measure that was considered impossible in the early stages of the Russian invasion of Ukraine because of the bloc’s high dependency on the fuel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis and Talmon Joseph Smith
title: After a Bumper 2021, Companies Might Struggle to Increase Profits
description: Businesses face headwinds as demand weakens, the Federal Reserve raises rates and government stimulus programs end.
content: The profits engine that drove stocks to their highs, making many Americans feel richer than they had in a generation, may now be working in reverse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: A Senate Democrat wants Wells Fargo’s C.E.O. to fix its problems ‘once and for all.’
description: Senator Sherrod Brown of Ohio, the chairman of the chamber’s Banking Committee, rebuked Charles W. Scharf for the bank’s continued problems.
content: The Democrat in charge of the Senate Banking Committee is not happy with Wells Fargo’s chief executive, Charles W. Scharf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump Policies Sent U.S. Tumbling in a Climate Ranking
description: The Environmental Performance Index, published every two years by researchers at Yale and Columbia, found only Denmark and Britain on sustainable paths to net-zero emissions by 2050.
content: For four years under President Donald J. Trump, the United States all but stopped trying to combat climate change at the federal level. Mr. Trump is no longer in office, but his presidency left the country far behind in a race that was already difficult to win.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Forces Battle for Ukraine City, as E.U. Ratchets Up Responses
description: As Russian forces advanced into Sievierodonetsk, Ukraine’s allies promised increased aid, a sharp drop in Russian oil imports and efforts to ship Ukrainian grain out of the country.
content: BRUSSELS — Russian troops battled their way into the devastated Ukrainian city of Sievierodonetsk on Tuesday, as their slow, brutal offensive in eastern Ukraine shifted from indiscriminate shelling to street fighting, with thousands of civilians still trapped among the ruins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kendall Ciesemier
title: Misusing Words Like ‘Groomer’ Isn’t Just Wrong. It’s Dangerous.
description: A child in danger cannot find safety if the language we use to define abuse is diluted.
content: The person who sexually abused me when I was 5 years old is someone I could describe as a “groomer,” a “pedophile” or a “child molester.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Coco Gauff Advances to French Open Semifinals
description: Gauff beat Sloane Stephens to reach the semifinals of a Grand Slam singles tournament for the first time in her career.
content: After graduating from online high school, Coco Gauff is in a new phase of her tennis career, and she is marking the occasion at the French Open in her favorite city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charmaine Patricia Warren
title: For a Young Choreographer, Bed-Stuy Is Home and a Stage
description: “Everything I need is right here,” Jordan Demetrius Lloyd said of his Brooklyn neighborhood. Add to that his new work, “Jerome,” staged in a schoolyard near his home.
content: Call it a bold move. In his five years as a choreographer, Jordan Demetrius Lloyd has made dances for black box theaters and dances on film. But after two isolating years of pandemic life, he wanted to do something different, something that would honor his neighborhood, Bedford-Stuyvesant, in Brooklyn, and his neighbors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Dana Cowin Returns to Print With a Zine, Speaking Broadly
description: The former editor in chief of Food & Wine has named her new publication after her podcast.
content: Dana Cowin, who was the editor in chief of Food & Wine magazine for 21 years and left in 2016, is back in the editorial game with a new zine called Speaking Broadly. The project, which shares its name with her podcast, was put on hold for two years because of the pandemic, but it has now come back to life. It’s defined by bright, bold pages designed by Meagan Bennett, and features women in food. In the first issue there are essays called “Meals With Meaning,” a graphic tour of orange wine for a “Tastebud Training Course,” a guide to Mexico City restaurants by local residents, some personal essays, recipes, product reviews and more. Ms. Cowin has published it herself. It can be ordered online.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: Help Wanted: State Misinformation Sheriff
description: Several states are putting more money and effort into combating false and misleading information about elections.
content: Ahead of the 2020 elections, Connecticut confronted a bevy of falsehoods about voting that swirled around online. One, widely viewed on Facebook, wrongly said absentee ballots had been sent to dead people. On Twitter, users spread a false post that a tractor-trailer carrying ballots had crashed on Interstate 95, sending thousands of voter slips into the air and across the highway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Egan
title: Bill McKibben, American Idealist, Sours on America’s Ideals
description: In “The Flag, the Cross, and the Station Wagon,” an activist finds flaws in patriotism, faith and suburban life and urges fellow baby boomers to change.
content: THE FLAG, THE CROSS, AND THE STATION WAGONA Graying American Looks Back at His Suburban Boyhood and Wonders What the Hell HappenedBy Bill McKibben
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier, Mady Camara and Christiaan Triebert
title: ‘The Killings Didn’t Stop.’ In Mali, a Massacre With a Russian Footprint.
description: Civilian deaths have spiked in Mali since Russian mercenaries of the Wagner Group began operating alongside the military. In late March, hundreds were executed in the village of Moura.
content: BAMAKO, Mali — On the last Sunday in March before Ramadan, thousands of merchants and villagers filled the market of Moura, in central Mali, trading cattle in a vast pen and stocking up on spices and vegetables in the town’s sandy alleys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: How a Florida Power Project Flew Under the Regulatory Radar
description: The state’s biggest utility is building a 176-mile line that may be unsuitable or even unneeded. Its design minimized scrutiny. Critics see a pattern.
content: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — As Florida Power & Light described it, the plan seemed sound: a 176-mile transmission line allowing the utility to better handle peak electricity demand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Hungary’s oil embargo exemption is the latest sign of its leader’s affinity for Russia.
description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban has spoken admiringly of President Vladimir Putin and expressed sympathy for his security demands to NATO.
content: The European Union’s long-delayed deal to embargo Russian oil, finalized late Monday, effectively exempts Hungary from the costly step the rest of the bloc is taking to punish Russia for its invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
description: The European Union reached an agreement late Monday to ban most imports of Russian oil, a move that further severs ties between Europe and Russia and marks the harshest economic retribution Moscow has faced for its war in Ukraine.
content: The European Union reached an agreement late Monday to ban most imports of Russian oil, a move that further severs ties between Europe and Russia and marks the harshest economic retribution Moscow has faced for its war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: A Plea to Celebrate Life as Uvalde Faces Many Days of Mourning
description: A week after the shooting at Robb Elementary School, the nearly two dozen funerals have begun in a community that must contemplate an agonizing new reality.
content: UVALDE, Texas — Amerie Jo Garza, 10, a jokester who made the honor roll. Tuesday, 2 p.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: La Marchande, With Modernized French Fare, Opens in the Financial District
description: Upscale Italian from a longtime head captain, Spanish-influenced small plates in the East Village and more restaurant news.
content: Nearly 200 years ago, the financial district was New York City’s hub for fine dining. With Crown Shy, Harry’s, Nobu Downtown, Temple Court, the new Le Gratin and this gracious restaurant and bar by John Fraser in the Wall Street Hotel, it’s heading in that direction again. The hotel, owned by Paspaley, a major pearl company in Australia, is in a repurposed office building with a mercantile past. (The restaurant’s name — “the merchant” in French — reflects that.) An elegant bar leads to a white-tablecloth dining room with an elaborate raw bar and a couple of semiprivate tables framed in heavy drapes. Despite the formality of the setting, Mr. Fraser hopes to attract what he sees as a younger crowd who live and work in the area, by modernizing the French fare that shaped his career in Paris. “I’m looking at the 21st century, using global ingredients, sometimes out of left field,” he said. He’s supported by his executive chef, Rick Horiike, who worked at Buddakan and Wild Ink. Among the raw-bar items and appetizers on the lengthy menu are beef tartare, asparagus or blue crab enclosed in rice paper rolls; littleneck clams with cilantro mignonette; and lightly seared duck breast, sliced carpaccio-thin, with a drizzle of fish sauce caramel. Main courses include sweet rice with mushrooms cooked in a banana leaf, a version of homard à l’Américaine made with coconut milk, coffee-crusted pork chop with lentils, trout baked with a basting of miso, and roasted or steamed Dover sole for two with vermouth-lime butter. Desserts include a floating island with Japanese-style cheesecake. Amy Racine, the beverage director for Mr. Fraser’s JF Restaurants, will oversee the 120-label wine list that, while mostly French, lists some Australian selections to honor the hotel’s owners. (Opens June 7)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Tallerico
title: ‘Stranger Things 4’: A Guide to the Major Pop Culture References
description: As in seasons past, this go-round is full of nods and Easter eggs to 1970s and ’80s pop culture, particularly onscreen. Here’s a roundup of the ones we caught.
content: This article contains major spoilers for Season 4 of “Stranger Things.” See some references we missed? Tell us about them in the comments section.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Precious Strawberry Drops Its Price
description: With a new indoor farm in a former beer brewery in New Jersey, Oishii strawberries have come down in price. But they’ll still set you back — $11 for six.
content: Bright local strawberries are showing up on farm stands and in the city’s Greenmarkets. Like the Hudson Valley and Long Island, New Jersey is a major source, but not just for seasonal field-grown fruit. A couple of indoor growers, Bowery Farming and Oishii, are cultivating them indoors with no seasonal limitations. They’re grown without pesticides and are sold at Tiffany prices. Now Oishii has just opened a major new indoor vertical farm in a former Anheuser-Busch plant in Jersey City, N.J., and the increased production is allowing the company to reduce prices by about half, so a tray of 11 delicious medium-size Omakase Berries is now $20, or six for $11. The Whole Foods in NoMad, 63 Madison Avenue (28th Street), which opens this week, is selling them, as are a number of the city’s high-end food retailers. Oishii’s berries might be worth considering once the local season, with berries for around $10 a quart, winds down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Student Contest Winner: Street Market Sweets
description: Vasudev Govind’s family has made a living selling imartis, a popular Indian street food, for generations, but in March 2020, the customers disappeared.
content: This piece is one of 10 winners of our 2022 Profile Contest. You can find more here. Gauri Gupta, the author, is 14 and goes to the The Cathedral and John Connon School in Mumbai, India.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Advisory firm urges Spirit shareholders to vote against merger with Frontier.
description: Institutional Shareholder Services, which advises large investors, said shareholders should opt for a higher offer for Spirit by JetBlue.
content: Spirit Airlines’s shareholders should vote against a proposed merger with Frontier Airlines in favor of a competing offer from JetBlue Airways, a prominent shareholder advisory firm recommended on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Putin’s Shadow Soldiers: How the Wagner Group Is Expanding in Africa
description: Best known for its mercenaries, the Wagner Group also mines diamonds, spreads disinformation and props up autocrats in an effort to grow Russia’s footprint.
content: Mercenaries are enjoying a resurgence in Africa, hired to fight in some of the continent’s most intractable conflicts. Perhaps the most famous outfit is the Wagner Group, a nebulous network that combines military force with commercial and strategic interests, now at the vanguard of Russia’s expanding ambitions in Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susie Linfield
title: Should We Be Forced to See Exactly What an AR-15 Does to a 10-Year-Old?
description: A violent society ought to view its handiwork.
content: I know that stoning people to death is barbaric. But I never understood just what it entails — the slow, cruel process by which a defenseless human being is degraded and destroyed — until I saw a series of photographs taken by Somali photojournalist Farah Abdi Warsameh, which depict the stoning execution of a man accused of adultery by the insurgent group Hizbul Islam. While some charge that viewing such pictures is voyeuristic, these images made me face the terror, the blood and the sheer cruelty of this practice — one that, astonishingly, has not yet been tossed into the dustbin of history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: The Doctor Prescribed an Obesity Drug. Her Insurer Called It ‘Vanity.’
description: Many insurance companies refuse to cover new weight loss drugs that their doctors deem medically necessary.
content: Maya Cohen’s entree into the world of obesity medicine came as a shock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Nadal Tops Djokovic at French Open in Thrilling Addition to Rivalry
description: Rafael Nadal’s match with Novak Djokovic lasted more than four hours. Nadal will face Alexander Zverev, the third seed, in a semifinal.
content: PARIS — For a man who did not want to play Novak Djokovic at night, Rafael Nadal certainly made the best of the situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Student Contest Winner: Fighting Against the Wind
description: Ynnel Villarias left her home to find work in Singapore. Then a typhoon hit, her hometown was destroyed and she couldn’t reach her children.
content: This piece is one of 10 winners of our 2022 Profile Contest. You can find more here. Yueyang Ge, the author, is 16 and goes to UWC South East Asia, Dover Campus, in Singapore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: A ‘Rake’ Takes a Treasured Spot in the Opera Season
description: The Met’s performances of Stravinsky’s “The Rake’s Progress” are the latest in a long line of short spring revivals of works off the beaten path.
content: Just before the end of this milestone comeback season at the Metropolitan Opera, the slot has returned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Ehrenreich
title: Barry Lopez Urged Us to Pay Attention to a Burning World
description: In a posthumous essay collection, Lopez asks readers “not to give in to the temptation to despair.”
content: “I would ask you,” writes Barry Lopez in one of the essays collected in “Embrace Fearlessly the Burning World,” “not to give in to the temptation to despair.” These days, it’s what you could call a Big Ask. Lopez, who before his death at 75 had traveled to more and stranger corners of the earth than most of us have bothered to imagine, certainly understood it as such. “To read the newspapers today, to merely answer the phone,” he wrote elsewhere, “is to know the world is in flames.” So perhaps his request is better read as a challenge — not only to readers but also to himself, a writer who, as long as he can keep our attention, holds our souls in his hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Spotlight Is on Produce All Summer Long at the Botanical Garden
description: At the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, artists and farmers celebrate edible plants with a new exhibition, “Around the Table.”
content: Food returns to center stage this summer at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx; beginning Saturday, displays throughout the garden will relate to produce as part of the exhibition “Around the Table.” Edible plants will be growing in the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory and will be featured in an African American garden curated by Dr. Jessica B. Harris. Artists from the Bronx have decorated 30 tables, works of other artists will be on display and there will be a showcase for cookbooks with plant-based recipes. Visitors with the grounds-only ticket will see some of the exhibition, but to see everything requires an all-garden pass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Texas Shooting Stokes Democrats’ Disagreements About the Police
description: President Biden recently issued an executive order aimed at overhauling policing. But while the move was widely praised, Democrats remain split about just how much to fund the police.
content: Last Wednesday, on the second anniversary of George Floyd’s death, President Biden unveiled a long-awaited executive order aimed at overhauling policing in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: I Thought Putin Invaded Only Ukraine. I Was Wrong.
description: Europe is more united than ever in the wake of the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
content: BERLIN — I’ve been writing nonstop about the Ukraine war ever since Russia invaded on Feb. 24, but I confess that it took coming to Europe and meeting with politicians, diplomats and entrepreneurs here for me to fully grasp what happened. You see, I thought Vladimir Putin had invaded Ukraine. I was wrong. Putin had invaded Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Storm Damages as Many as 100 Homes in Minnesota
description: There were no immediate reports of serious injuries after a possible tornado struck Forada, about 135 miles northwest of Minneapolis, a county official said.
content: A possible tornado struck Forada, a city of about 160 residents in central Minnesota, on Monday, downing power lines and damaging as many as 100 homes, a county official said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Descano
title: My Governor Can Pass Bad Abortion Laws. But I Won’t Enforce Them.
description: No matter what the law says, I’ll never prosecute a woman for getting an abortion. My fellow prosecutors need to step up and make the same promise.
content: Almost two and a half years ago, I took my oath of office as prosecutor, and swore to protect my community from those who broke the law. The real threat, I now realize, may stem from those who write the law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: ‘The Wire’ at 20: ‘This Show Will Live Forever’
description: David Simon and Ed Burns discuss the legacy of their seminal crime drama, and why the systemic decay it depicted has become only more profound.
content: David Simon concedes that it takes a special kind of [expletive] to say, “I told you so.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Was 20 and He Was 60’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: “Do you hear it?” the midwife asked. Holding a stethoscope to my newborn’s heart, I couldn’t hear anything. “Let me try removing my hearing aids,” I said. “Sometimes they get in the way.” I became a parent and learned I had hearing loss in the same year. Wyn, alert for being one week old, blinked at me. “You might not hear it, but you can feel it,” my husband said. He took the stethoscope, put it in his ears, and gently tapped out the heartbeat on my thigh — ba-bump, ba-bump — as I held our newborn in my arms. — Meggie Schmidt Hollinger
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel Signs Trade Deal With U.A.E.
description: The agreement highlighted deepening ties between Israel and parts of the Arab world. Once ratified, it will remove tariffs on 96 percent of bilateral trade, the two governments said.
content: JERUSALEM — Government ministers from Israel and the United Arab Emirates signed a free-trade agreement on Tuesday that, once ratified, would be the widest-ranging deal of its kind between Israel and an Arab country and the latest example of deepening ties between the Jewish state and some Arab governments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Student Contest Winner: An International Teacher on Showing Up for Life
description: Although every culture Carinn Mariani has experienced has helped her to grow as a teacher, her approach to education has stuck.
content: This piece is one of 10 winners of our 2022 Profile Contest. You can find more here. Brienne Mittleider, the author, is 17 and goes to Holy Trinity Episcopal Academy in Melbourne, Fla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Talk on Biltong and Other South African Delights
description: The Culinary Historians of New York will host a discussion on the foods and wines of South Africa with the linguists Keri and Kelsi Matwick.
content: The multicultural evolution of the food of South Africa over the past 400 years will be surveyed and explained by Keri and Kelsi Matwick, twin sisters who have graduate degrees in linguistics and now teach on the university level. On June 9 at 6:30 p.m. in a Zoom program for the Culinary Historians of New York, they will discuss several dishes, including biltong (a jerky made from game), Cape Malay curry, sadza maize porridge, malva pudding and wine. The sisters are recipients of scholar’s grants from the Culinary Historians of New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Ramzy
title: Crude, Ugly and Pro-American? China Investigates Images in Math Textbooks.
description: The discovery of what some viewed as disturbing illustrations in books for elementary school students set off a national furor.
content: HONG KONG — A little boy pulling up a girl’s dress. Another grabbing a classmate from behind, his hands across her chest. Bulges protruding from male students’ pants. Suspiciously pro-American images.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Russian Military Is Repeating Mistakes in Eastern Ukraine, U.S. Says
description: President Vladimir V. Putin sent in a new commander in April, but Russian troops are still facing morale and other problems, American officials say.
content: WASHINGTON — The Russian military, beaten down and demoralized after three months of war, is making the same mistakes in its campaign to capture a swath of eastern Ukraine that forced it to abandon its push to take the entire country, senior American officials say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Go Here, Not There: Vacation Alternatives for the Budget-Conscious
description: As inflation puts a crimp in travelers’ plans, here are some affordable suggestions for trips focused on wine, culture, food, the outdoors and more.
content: Inflation, high gas prices and soaring airfares are sponging up discretionary budgets, forcing Americans to rethink travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Taste the Rainbow This Pride Month
description: At Lady Wong in the East Village, a delicate Indonesian rainbow cake made with natural dyes is a sweet way to celebrate.
content: June is Pride Month and to celebrate, the chefs Seleste Tan and Mogan Anthony — the owners of Lady Wong, an East Village bakery that specializes in Southeast Asian confections — offer a dazzling steamed Indonesian rainbow cake. The petite stack of thin, multicolored, slightly spongy gelatinous layers is meant to be eaten by peeling them off one by one. It’s made from coconut milk and palm sugar, and the layers are dyed naturally, with beets, turmeric and pandan; the flavor is sweet, but not cloyingly so, with a whisper of coconut. Twenty-five percent of sales of the cake will be donated to the Hetrick-Martin Institute for LGBTQIA+ Youth. Similar snacks, called kuih, are sold at the shop, as are rich desserts like a pandan tiramisù, a cassava cake and a passion fruit-calamansi cake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Killer Asteroids Are Hiding in Plain Sight. A New Tool Helps Spot Them.
description: Researchers have built an algorithm that can scan old astronomical images for unnoticed space rocks, helping to detect objects that could one day imperil Earth.
content: Ed Lu wants to save Earth from killer asteroids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Just One Little Bite
description: Find hidden meaning in Chase Dittrich’s puzzle.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Chase Dittrich, who is making his fourth appearance in the New York Times Crossword with today’s puzzle. Mr. Dittrich, as he explains in his notes, is passionate about gaming, as are we here in the Games section of The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: ‘Notes on Killing’ Review: For These Puerto Ricans, Promises Never Kept
description: Mara Vélez Meléndez’s “Notes on Killing Seven Oversight, Management and Economic Stability Board Members” ferociously explores the intersection of the personal and the political.
content: “Notes on Killing Seven Oversight, Management and Economic Stability Board Members,” a hot and bothered new play by Mara Vélez Meléndez, is a psychodrama with an emphasis on — and I mean this in the nicest possible way — psycho.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Alaska’s environmental battles
description: Sometimes, the disputes are like the state itself: huge. Here’s why.
content: Long-running environmental disputes in Alaska are like the state’s volcanoes. They can be quiet for years, but rumble to life now and then, venting a little steam here, a little lava there. Only once in a while is there a full-blown eruption.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: Rallying on the Streets for a Russian Oil Embargo
description: As European leaders flocked to Brussels to nail down a decision on banning most imports of Russian oil, young activists streamed in, too.
content: As European leaders flocked to Brussels to nail down a decision on banning most imports of Russian oil, young activists streamed in, too.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Essential Gear for a Summer of Cycling
description: Get equipped with the biking gear you need before you hit the road this summer.
content: Get equipped with the biking gear you need before you hit the road this summer.

description: The renovation preserved many of the home’s original details, but emphasized unexpected details and carefree weekend living.

title: Moroccan Flavors Served in Clay Pots
description: Tagine is a two-piece clay pot from Morocco. It’s also an aromatic stew cooked in that pot, and the specialty of a Queens restaurant called Dar Yemma.

title: Outrage Over the Delay at Uvalde: ‘A Total Failure of Law Enforcement’
